data.name: FleeExpressionCondition`1_FleeExpression.Help
data.value:
Enter here a boolean expression to be matched as a condition to trigger the sub strategy.

The expression is evaluated using Fast Lightweight Expression Evaluator, an open source expression engine, which allows fast computation thanks to byte code emission.

  • All expressions are dynamically built on first call and then cached for very fast retrieval and evaluation.
  • You should refer to the language reference to build your expressions.
  • The engine uses static type imports to enhance the set of available methods. the import includes all methods from the "System.Math" static class and all methods from the default types (object, int, char, string etc.)
  • The engine uses the concept of a dedicated Expression owner to supply the available variables. The expression owner is of type "Aricie.DNN.Modules.PortalKeeper.PortalKeeperContext, Aricie.PortalKeeper", which contains many properties giving access to the Http and DotNetNuke context.
  • If your expression does not evaluate properly, you should find exception reports in the DNN event log with hints for a correction

    • Here are a couple of sample valid expressions to get you started:

  • Match if the current user is authenticated:
    DnnContext.IsAuthenticated
  • Match if the current user is a member of the dnn role "Customers":
    DnnContext.User.IsInRole("Customers")
  • Match if the current request is secure (Https):
    DnnContext.HttpContext.Request.IsSecureConnection()
  • Match if the current user email contains "aricie.fr":
    DnnContext.User.Email.Contains("aricie.fr")
  • Match if the current page name contains "secure"
    DnnContext.Portal.ActiveTab.TabName.contains("secure")

data.name: FirewallSettings_RecoveryParam.Help
data.value:
Portal Keeper applies restrictions on authorized accesses to your portal according to specific conditions; accordingly you might find yourself locked out without a mean to log as an admin user anymore (for instance if your ISP changes your static IP without prior notice... yes, we had that one once !).

Enter here a secret string, which when found in the url -for instance as a querystring parameter- will temporarily disable the firewall. Make sure to choose a complex string, to test it with your target settings enabled, and keep it in a safe location

data.name: StringTransformInfo_FilterType.Help
data.value:
Choose here the type of transformation you wish to define. There are three types available:

  • Regex transforms let you enter a source regular expression to match and replacement expression.
  • String transforms let you enter a source string and a replacement string or nothing to remove the string
  • Chars transforms let you enter a source list of chars as a concatenated string and either
    • a concatenated string of the same size for a char by char replacement mapping
    • an empty string to remove all of the source chars
    • a single char to replace each of the source chars with the single target char

data.name: FirewallConfig_EnablePortalLevelSettings.Help
data.value: You can optionally enable portal specific settings. If enabled portal administrators will get access to a restricted set of parameters, which will be merged at runtime with the host configuration. Beware that the admin config is not available before the end of the begin request event.

data.name: FirewallConfig_EnableStopWatch.Help
data.value: You can optionally enable a stop watch to record request event timings in dnn event log. The "DebugInfo" Log type must be activated. The measurements give indications of the firewall overhead.

data.name: ProviderConfig_TypeName.Required
data.value: A Provider type name is needed. Generic types can be entered following the existing examples' syntax

data.name: RequestsCapInfo_MaxNbNewSources.Help
data.value: In order to account for widely distributed attacks, you can optionally define a max number of new sources accepted per duration. If that cap is reached during any "time window" of the configured duration. Such a window is banned as a whole instead of only the corresponding source. As a consequence, any client, which connected for the first time during the same window will match regardless its individual request rate. Accordingly, this may result in banning a handful of legitimate users, yet provides a very robust additional protection against widespread attacks, where no single client rate matched yet a very large number of clients suddenly request the server over a short period of time.

data.name: FleeExpressionInfo`1_Variables.Help
data.value:
In order for the expression to compile, variables must be explicitally typed. The set of available types can be updated in the next section.
There are 2 types of variables:
  • CtorVariable, only available when the target type has a default parameterless constructor, which resolve through calling the corresponding constructor.
  • ExpressionVariable, which is made from a complete sub Flee Expression
    • /ul>

data.name: VariableInfo_EvaluationMode.Help
data.value: There are 2 modes of evaluation, Constant, which means the variable is only computed on the first evaluation and then Dynamic, which means the variable is computed on each evaluation and may depend on the context. Flee engine can deal with chaining comiled sub-expression to keep performances optimal.

data.name: Variables_ExpressionTypes.Help

data.value: The expression should account for the delcared variable type. You may use in turn sub-variables, to be evaluated once as constants or to be chained to the current expression. In such a case, sub-expressions are cloned for better performances.

data.name: ExpressionVariableInfo`1_FleeExpression.Text

data.name: RuleEngineSettings`1_Variables.Help
data.value:
You can use any parameter defined here by its name in any expression based condition/action. You can update the list of .Net types available below. For each .Net type, you can choose amongst at most 3 kinds of variables to define a new parameter:
  • VariableInfo : An instance of the .Net type will be created and saved together with the configuration. You can edit the properties for that instance directly in the configuration form
  • cTorVariableInfo : your parameter is created by calling a constructor of the corresponding .Net type. You can choose to pass parameters to the constructor.
  • ExpressionVariableInfo : your parameter is defined by evaluating a Flee expression (see the corresponding help lables for more information).

Profile Property lets you define the Field as in DNN's native profile property editor.

data.name: BotFarmInfo`1_EncryptionKey.Help

Accordingly, users should backup their bot parameters before they update their profile email address. The encryption key itself is stored encrypted against a fingerprint of the current DNN hosting Instance.

data.name: ExchangeInfo_AskCommission.Help
data.value: This is the transaction fee in percentage applied on ask orders

data.name: ExchangeInfo_BidCommission.Help
data.value: This is the transaction fee in percentage applied on bid orders. It may be different from the Ask Commission when a double commission is applied on the order value and on the amount purchased.

data.name: ExchangeInfo_Filter.Help

data.name: ExchangeInfo_MinOrderAmount.Help
data.value: This is the amount for the lowest ask / highest bid issuable by the bot

data.name: ExchangeInfo_PriceDecil.Help
data.value: This is the number of decimals the exchange takes for order prices

data.name: TradingStrategy_AdjustOrderLimitRate.Help
data.value: This is the limit, below which an order is increased, in percentage of the ideal amount defined by the amount expression

data.name: TradingStrategy_LimitOrderValueRate.Help
data.value:
(% Max Order Value)
The pricer defines a profit margin band around the current price where no order is issued. This parameter defines the value of the limit central orders as a percentage of the outer orders.

data.name: TradingStrategy_DefaultMaxOrderValueRate.Help
data.value:
(Value % available btc/$ )
When defining a new band, this the percentage of available resource allocated to the upper/lower bound order

data.name: TradingStrategy_DefaultBandWidthRate.Help
data.value:
(Current Price +- X %)
This defines the default upper/lower orders, within which the trading bot will place other open orders. Manual orders can discard this value, which is only used when there is no ask/bid existing order.

data.name: TradingStrategy_VolumeGrowthLimitFactor.Help
data.value: This accounts for adjusting the trading band by increasing the outer bound orders thus the trading volume, when the available resources increase. If the extreme orders value multiplied by this parameter are found to be less than the available resource, those orders are increased using the following parameter.

data.name: TradingStrategy_VolumeGrowthRate.Help
data.value: This is the percentage of available resource used to increase the amount of the corresponding outer order

data.name: RuleEngineSettings`1_EnableStopWatch.Help
data.value: You can optionally enable a stop watch to record engine event timings in dnn event log. The "DebugInfo" Log type must be activated. The measurements give indications of the firewall overhead.

data.name: ActionProvider`1_SleepTime.Help
data.value: You can optionally define a period to wait after the action is performed

data.name: TradingStrategyBase_AskReserveRate.Help
data.value: This is the percentage of btcs you keep off trading. Note that if the available resource decrease, so does the reserved resource

data.name: TradingStrategyBase_BidReserveRate.Help
data.value: This is the percentage of usds you keep off trading. Note that if the available resource decrease, so does the reserved resource

data.name: TradingStrategy_LimitOrderMarginRate.Help
data.value:
(% Order Price)
The central margin band where no orders are issued is defined by the exchange transaction fee and an additional margin defined by this parameter as a percentage of the current price.

data.name: RuleEngineSettings`1_EnableSimpleLogs.Help
data.value: The Debug Timer generates a lot of dnn events for each. The simple logger only logs run start/end together with dumped variables serialized if enabled

data.name: TradingStrategy_BandWidthMarginRate.Help
data.value: If the ticker gets too close to one of the extreme orders by this percentage, a new bandwidth is defined and the open orders broken up to this new band.

data.name: TradingStrategy_InterTradeReserve.Help
data.value: This the percentage of resources alocated to trading reserved for subsequent bot run.

data.name: ActionProvider`1_AlternateAction.Help

data.name: ActionProvider`1_ConditionalAction.Help

data.name: TradingStrategy_CancelOrderLimitRate.Help
data.value: In case of varying order density, this attempts to maintain the desired price distribution/density. An order is cancelled if the span between that order and the next one is found smaller than the following span by less than the percentage defined by this parameter.

data.name: ActionProvider`1_AddSleepTime.Help
data.value: You can optionally define a time span to wait after the action was performed. This is useful for instance if you're constrained by rate cap on external web requests

data.name: BotFarmInfo`1_Bots.Help
data.value: Each bot has its own schedule and rule engine. You may use the import/export feature to copy elements between bots, yet you should always start with making sure that the target bot has got the needed providers properly registered.

data.name: TradingStrategy_AskOrderAmountExpression.Help
data.value: This is the expression to compute an ask order amount given its price. It is used both for new orders and existing order updates. For advanced editing, the variables are brought by a Flee expression context owner with .Net type TradingContext.

data.name: TradingStrategy_BidOrderAmountExpression.Help
data.value: This is the expression to compute a bid order amount given its price. It is used both for new orders and existing order updates. For advanced editing, the variables are brought by a Flee expression context owner with .Net type TradingContext.

data.name: TradingStrategy_MaxBidOrderPriceExpression.Help
data.value: This defines how new inner bid orders are defined starting from the highest existing bid order, getting closer to the current price, until the central margin band is reached.. For advanced editing, the variables are brought by a Flee expression context owner with .Net type TradingContext.

data.name: TradingStrategy_MinAskOrderPriceExpression.Help
data.value: This defines how new inner ask orders are defined starting from the lowest existing ask order, getting closer to the current price, until the central margin band is reached.. For advanced editing, the variables are brought by a Flee expression context owner with .Net type TradingContext.

data.name: BotFarmInfo`1_Schedule.Help
data.value:
The DNN scheduler task running the farm is set to run every minute.

Now each bot can be individually scheduled to a shorter period. Accordingly, this minimum schedule allows to run the farm several times within each DNN scheduler period. The corresponding sub period should be less than the shortest bot period. Also, if you have several bots, some of which require a lengthy execution, you should make sure to configure them to run asynchronously.

Note, that unless you get a constant traffic, you'll get the most accurate results with timer mode. The asynchronous autoping bot helps mitigating that effect

data.name: SimulationInfo_FastSimulation.Help

Enabling fast simulation mode attempts to detect those period an skip running the bot until an existing open order gets executed or a significant price variation is observed. This allows for much faster simulations, yet you should check that the results fit the regular mode upon validating a new strategy.

data.name: ActionProvider`1_SemaphoreName.Help
data.value: This is the system-wide name that will indentify your blocking semaphore. Example: HttpRequest-www.cryptsy.com

data.name: ActionProvider`1_SynchronisationTimeout.Help
data.value: Set a non zero value if you want a blocked thread to give up waiting after a time out. In such a case, the action is skipped and returns false

data.name: ActionProvider`1_UseSemaphore.Help
data.value: When you start running agents or actions asynchronously, you may observe that several actions run simultaneously. This might be detrimental in certain cases: for instance you may want to control the rate of concurrent http requests to a particular domain to avoid reaching advertised limits. Using a semaphore ensures that only a certain amount of concurrent threads can enter a named section simulatneously. Use that mechanims together with the addition of sleep time to precisally adjut the running rate. Also, if you run a web farm, you might have to make sure that your bot is configured to run on a single server.

data.name: TaskQueueInfo_EnablePerformanceCounters.Help
data.value: If checked, this enable collecting Smart Thread Pool performances to a dedicated Windows Performance Counter

data.name: TaskQueueInfo_PerformanceCounterInstanceName.Help
data.value: The Name of your custom Data collector. Since all asynchronous queues will log the same metrics, choose a name to identify this particular queue.

data.name: UserBotInfo_IsAuthenticated.Help

data.name: UserVariableInfo_UseSubStorage.Help

data.name: BotInfo`1_RunSeveralInstances.Help

data.name: BotInfo`1_SharedContext.Help
data.value: When several instances are started, the initial bot context is cloned for a fresh start on each run. Sharing the context saves some time, but it will certainly bring erroneous results, although Monitors are generally used to prevent cross thread locks.

data.name: TaskQueueInfo_IdleTimeout.Help
data.value: The Task Queue engine uses the smartthreadpool component, which is capable of adjusting the number of active threads up to the specified thread number. When a thread is idle, it is stopped after the given timeout to free resources.

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_AdaptedControlPath.Help

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_AdaptedControlType.Help
data.value: The is the qualified .Net type of the control to be adapted.

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_AdaptedMode.Help
data.value: You can either designate a control to be adapted by its .Net type name, or by its path for a Page or a User Control. The latter is paticularly userful with codefile user control, the assembly of which might be unknown at runtime. The underlying .Net type is obtained by instanciating the control once.

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_AdapterControlType.Help
data.value: The is the qualified .Net type of the adapter control class; it should inherit directly or indirectly from the ControlAdapter base class.

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_DynamicHandlers.Help
data.value: Dynamic Handlers are individual actions to be attached to a life cycle event of a control or a child control .

data.name: DynamicHandlerSettings_HandlerRegistrationStep.Help

data.name: DynamicHandlerSettings_BaseHandlerMode.Help

data.name: DynamicHandlerSettings_ChildControlId.Help

data.name: DynamicHandlerSettings_ControlEventName.Help

data.name: DynamicHandlerSettings_MainControlStep.Help

data.name: PortalKeeperConfig_ControlAdapters.Help

data.name: PortalKeeperConfig_ControlAdapters.Text

data.name: ProfileActionProviderBase`1_ProfileType.Help
data.value:
There are 2 user profile which you can access:
  • the identity user profile (with a dedicated form, which the user can edit).
    • ,
  • the personalization user profile (that one is rarely used and does not have an edit form associated, it is intended to customize user experience).

data.name: ProfileActionProviderBase`1_PropertyName.Help
data.value: This is the name of the profile property to access

data.name: ProfileActionProviderBase`1_UserMode.Help
data.value:
There are several ways to select the user, the profile of which to be accessed:
  • Current user: implies that the action is run in an authenticated context, the authenticated user is choosen
  • By User Id: you have to explicitally indicate the portal and the user id or an integer expression that resolves into the user id
  • By Username : you have to explicitally indicate the portal and the target user's Username or a string expression that resolves into the username
  • By Userinfo: You have to supply a UserInfo expression that resolves into the targetted user entity

data.name: FleeExpressionInfo`1_OverrideOwner.Help
data.value: The Flee Compiler used for code expressions has the underlying concept of an Expression Owner. By default, the current instance of PortalKeeperContext is passed as an expression owner of all expressions. You can alternatively supply a simple expression that resolves into the desired context owner. One big advantage is the posibility to access private members without relying on time consuming Reflection operations.

data.value: This is the selected type accounting for open or closed generic parameters

data.name: DotNetType_GenericTypes.Help
data.value: Those are the generic argument to close the open generic type definition selected above. You can leave the type empty for open / semi-open definition

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_AdatedPathMode.Help
data.value: You can choose to manually enter a relative path to a control to be adapted, or to select amongst a selection of files

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_ResolvedAdaptedControlTypeName.Help
data.value: This is the dot net type for the adapted control resolved from the configuration above. Note that if you use a user control path, the adapted control is the server generated class inheriting the codebehind class rather than the codebehind itself.

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_ResolvedAdapterControlTypeName.Help
data.value: This is the dot net type for the adapter control resolved from the configuration above. It can be a typed adapter or a dynamic adapter.

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_AdaptedControlPath.Required
data.value: You must enter a control path to be adapted

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_AdaptedSelectedPath.Help
data.value: This is a selection of all ascx user control and aspx pages found in the Application

data.name: ControlAdapterSettings_AdaptedSelectedPath.Required

data.name: GeneralObjectAction_ActionMode.Help
data.value: There are 3 types of object action you can perform on an object: Set a property, call a method or add an event handler. Corresponding controls should appear according to you selection.

data.name: GeneralObjectAction_DelegateExpression.Help
data.value: This is an expression that resolved into an object of type Delegate. You can create Delegates when defining variables. For now, you should make sure the target delegate and even handler's signatures do match.

data.name: GeneralObjectAction_DotNetType.Help
data.value: Select a type of object, on which you want to perform an action

data.name: GeneralObjectAction_EventName.Help
data.value: Select an event amongst those declared on the target object type

data.name: GeneralObjectAction_Instance.Help
data.value: This is an expression for the object on which you wish to perform an action. Typically a local variable, leave empty if you want to access a static member

data.name: GeneralObjectAction_Parameters.Help
data.value: Add the .Net types corresponding to the choosen constructor parameters first.

data.name: GeneralObjectAction_Parameters.Text
data.value: Enter the parameters to pass to your method or in case of an indexed property

data.name: GeneralObjectAction_PropertyName.Help
data.value: This is the name of the property to be set (readonly properties are filtered out)

data.name: GeneralObjectAction_PropertyValue.Help
data.value: Enter an object expression for the value to set. As it is passed as an object by reflection, you must ensure type safety by yourself

data.name: CallObjectMethod`1_MethodIndex.Help
data.value: When several signatures exist for the method you selected, enter the base-1 index for the target method

data.name: EncryptionInfo_EditInitVector.Help
data.value: This an auto generated Init Vector Bytes for symmetrical encryption and addtional entropy, base64 encoded.

data.name: EncryptionInfo_IsSealApplicationEncrypted.Help
data.value: The encryption keys are initially kept visible and editable. You can choose to seal them into the application which encrypts the private key with the main application decryption key. Only the same application will be able to recover the key at runtime.

data.name: EncryptionInfo_IsSealDataProtected.Help
data.value: The encryption keys are initially kept visible and editable. You can choose to seal them into the machine which encrypts the private key using the native ProtectedData methods. Only the same system and impersonated user will be able to recover the key at runtime.

data.name: EncryptionInfo_IsSealInKeyContainer.Help
data.value: The encryption keys are initially kept visible and editable. You can choose to seal them into the host operating system with the creation of a dedicated CSPContainer Key which encrypts the private key . Only the same system will be able to recover the key at runtime.

data.name: EncryptionInfo_PublicKeyAsCSPBlob.Help
data.value: This is the base64 representation of a CSP Blob export for the public key derived from the asymmetrical private key.

data.name: EncryptionInfo_PublicKeyAsRSAParameters.Help
data.value: This is the base64 representation of an instance of the RSAParameters structure, from an export from the public key derived from the asymmetrical private key.

data.name: EncryptionInfo_PublicKeyAsXml.Help
data.value: This is the Xml string format of the public key derived from the asymmetrical private key as returned by AsymmetricalAlgorithm.ExportXml(false)

data.name: EncryptionInfo_PublicKeyDisplay.Help
data.value: You can choose to display the public key in various format: Xml parameters, CspBlob or RSAParameters

data.name: EncryptionInfo_SelectedEncryptionType.Help
data.value: Your encryption manger can perform symmetric encryption, asymmetric encryption or both. symmetric encryption uses salted RijndaelManaged, Asymmetric Encryption uses a RsaCryptoProvider

data.name: GeneralObjectAction_MethodIndex.Help
data.value: When several signatures exist for the method you selected, enter the base-1 index for the target method

data.name: GeneralObjectAction_MethodName.Help
data.value: Select the name of the method you want to call on the target object

data.name: RSAParametersInfo_D.Help
data.value: Represents the D parameter for the RSA algorithm.

data.name: RSAParametersInfo_DP.Help
data.value: Represents the DP parameter for the RSA algorithm.

data.name: RSAParametersInfo_DQ.Help
data.value: Represents the DQ parameter for the RSA algorithm.

data.name: RSAParametersInfo_Exponent.Help
data.value: Represents the Exponent parameter for the RSA algorithm.

data.name: RSAParametersInfo_InverseQ.Help
data.value: Represents the InverseQ parameter for the RSA algorithm.

data.name: RSAParametersInfo_Modulus.Help
data.value: Represents the Modulus parameter for the RSA algorithm.

data.name: RSAParametersInfo_P.Help
data.value: Represents the P parameter for the RSA algorithm.

data.name: RSAParametersInfo_Q.Help
data.value: Represents the Q parameter for the RSA algorithm.

data.name: TaskQueueInfo_ThreadPriority.Help
data.value: This is the priority that will be assigned to the threads processing the queue. The wait time can also help defining priority hierarchies between concurrent operations

data.name: EncryptionInfo_AsymmetricKeySize.Help
data.value: This is the size of the RSACryptoServiceProvider's key used for asymmetric encryption

data.name: EncryptionInfo_DNNSalt.Help
data.value: This is the salt that was generated upon application level sealing

data.name: EncryptionInfo_EncryptionTypes.Help
data.value: You can perform several round of encryption using your asymmetric and symmetric keys. Beware of size limitation and performance costs of asymmetric encryption

data.name: EncryptionInfo_SymmetricKeySize.Help
data.value: This is the size of the RijndelManaged's key used for symmetric encryption

data.name: SealInKeyContainer.Alert
data.value: Warning: You are about to seal your encryption keys. Make sure you have a copy of them, since they won't be available through the UI nor the API anymore.

data.name: SealInKeyContainer.Completed
data.value: Your keys were sealed in a local key container. Don't forget to save your new configuration. If you want to move your data to a new DotNetNuke instance, you will need to reset and manually restore the previous keys in order for the existing data to be properly processed.

data.name: SealProtectData.Alert
data.value: Warning: You are about to seal your encryption keys. Make sure you have a copy of them, since they won't be available through the UI nor the API anymore.

data.name: SealProtectData.Completed
data.value: Your keys were sealed with local cryptoapis through ProtectedData methods. Don't forget to save your new configuration. If you want to move your data to a new DotNetNuke instance, you will need to reset and manually restore the previous keys in order for the existing data to be properly processed.

data.name: EncryptionInfo_EditProtectedDataEntropy.Help
data.value: A data protection seal relies on a call to Micrososft's DAPI attached to the impersonated user. That encrypted blob adds additional entropy for offuscation from distinct apps.

data.name: GeneralVariableInfo_DotNetType.Help
data.value: Select a .Net type for your variable.

data.name: GeneralVariableInfo_AsCompiledExpression.Help
data.value: If your variable is only to be used in subsequent Flee Expression, you can choose to postpone its evaluation and pass the compiled expression for direct integration in a wrapping expression, in order to optimize the resulting performances

data.name: GeneralVariableInfo_FleeExpression.Help
data.value: The expression should account for the delcared variable type. You may use in turn sub-variables, to be evaluated once as constants or to be chained to the current expression. In such a case, sub-expressions are cloned for better performances.

data.name: GeneralVariableInfo_FleeExpression.Text
data.value: Enter here the Flee Expression to initiate the variable

data.name: GeneralVariableInfo_Instance.Help
data.value: Edit the entity's properties directly below

data.name: GeneralVariableInfo_InstanceMode.Help
data.value: Instance mode lets your save and edit a version of the expression result obtained by evaluating the expression once. You can either choose to immediately evaluate the current variable with a default context, or to leave to evaluate in context, refresh the form to display the saved entity and save the form together with the new entity.

data.name: GeneralVariableInfo_Parameters.Help
data.value: Define here the parameters to be passed to the constructor. Static evaluation is forced.

data.name: GeneralVariableInfo_SimpleExpression.Help
data.value: The simple display lets you edit the expression text only

data.name: GeneralVariableInfo_UseClone.Help
data.value: If checked, a clone of the variable is returned instead of the variable itself. This allows for subsequent modifications without the original variable being affected.

data.name: GeneralVariableInfo_VariableMode.Help
data.value: There are 4 ways to define your variable:
